author: Nirbhay Thakur
title: Delhi consumer court orders hair transplant clinic to pay Rs 6.3 lakh to man who saw 'not even 1% improvement' | The Indian Express
text:
Delhi consumer court orders hair transplant clinic to pay Rs 6.3 lakh to man who saw ‘not even 1% improvement’
The Delhi consumer court found that the hair transplant clinic was operating without a government licence to perform modern hair transplant procedures.
Nirbhay ThakurJuly 3, 2025 10:57 IST
The New Delhi District Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission recently directed a hair transplant clinic to pay Rs 6.3 lakh compensation to a client after finding it guilty of negligence in providing service. The Commission also noted that DHI Asian Roots was operating without a government licence to perform modern hair transplant procedures.
The complainant, Vivek Kumar, approached the DHI Asian Roots clinic in Safdarjung Enclave in 2012 before his marriage to treat baldness and paid Rs 5 lakh. He alleged before the Commission that he was promised results after 12 months, but even after three sittings, he could not notice “even 1 per cent improvement” with his receding hairline. He filed a complaint with the Commission in December 2023.
The Commission’s order, dated May 22, which followed an 11-year legal battle, directed DHI Asian Roots to refund Rs 5 lakh to Kumar, along with Rs 1 lakh for mental harassment and Rs 30,000 for litigation costs.
“…this Commission is of the considered opinion that there is negligence/ deficiency in service on the part of the opposite parties (DHI) in not providing proper treatment to the complainant despite charging for the same. This is a case where opposite parties transplanted the hairs to cover bald area and created another bald area by over harvesting the donor area,” the Commission held.
“The OP/DHI-Asian Roots, a unit of SPA Yoga Pvt. Ltd… failed to produce any document showing authorization or license to perform modern scientific hair implantation procedures. They also lacked government approval to engage doctors…for such treatments,” held the Commission.
“The procedure conducted amounted to an unfair medical trade practice, carried out without the requisite licenses or specialized expertise, and appeared motivated solely by financial gain,” it added.
Countering Kumar’s allegations, DHI Asian Roots argued that it provided professional treatment in accordance with medical standards and that the chances of success had been explained to him.
It also alleged that Kumar’s dissatisfaction stemmed from his impatience and his “disregard for medical advice”. It claimed that Kumar had been informed about the procedure’s limitations and that all the pros and cons of the surgery had been explained to him.

author: NewsBreak Original
title: COLUMN: Start the New Year with the North Port Chamber
text: The North Port Area Chamber of Commerce success in 2023 was made possible by you — a remarkable and committed group of business owners, company leaders, local government officials, nonprofit partners and volunteers. You enabled us to fulfill our mission of advancing economic growth and quality of life for our members and our community. As we reflect on this past year, we thank you for your continued support of the North Port Area Chamber of Commerce. Our events and programs helped our members navigate a unique set of business opportunities and challenges. Your involvement also provided the networking and resources necessary for North Port area businesses to prosper. We play a unique role in our community. We not only serve almost 700-member businesses and organizations, but we work for the betterment of the North Port area. It is amazing who we bring to the table, including committed and talented people from family-owned service and retail businesses, large manufacturing companies, retailers, healthcare providers, nonprofit organizations and area educators. Now, there is more work ahead. Our chamber team has determined ways we can serve you best in 2024. We believe the upcoming year will be exciting and pivotal for the North Port area business community. We pledge to be hyper-focused on the best interests of North Port’s economy and to be your voice in important local decisions. The North Port Area Chamber of Commerce stands ready and committed to serving you. The new year is a good time for everyone to assess opportunities and determine a path going forward. We have done that. In 2024, our Chamber leaders and staff resolve to: • Remain your independent, local chamber of commerce. • Serve the North Port area economic community. • Be an information and marketing resource for North Port area businesses and community. • Collaborate with organizations who share our mission of advancing North Port’s economic growth and quality of life. We have a lot of exciting plans in 2024 and can’t wait to share them with you. We encourage you to stay in touch through our website and on our social media channels. We invite you to register for our events and programs in 2024 to connect and learn. Thank you for believing in the North Port Area Chamber of Commerce as we work to make our community a special place to live, work, play and belong. I would like to wish everyone a healthy, happy and prosperous new year. BREAKFAST PLANNING SESSION We’re having a special January Breakfast Club networking event at 7:30 a.m. Jan. 3, at the North Port Moose Lodge 764, 14156 Tamiami Trail. We’ll be soliciting topics for the 2024 Lunch & Learn Workshop series at this breakfast. There is no cost to attend, unless you wish to order a meal off of their delicious breakfast menu. Since the Lunch & Learn Workshops are free and open to all, registration for this special breakfast meeting is open to all as well. Register on our Event Page at www.northportareachamber.com. RIBBON-CUTTING CEREMONY Everyone is invited to a ribbon-cutting ceremony for Restoring Oaks at the chamber office, 14140 Tamiami Trail at 4 p.m. Thursday. Restoring Oaks is an organization that helps prevent and end human trafficking. The ceremony is free. Register at www.northportareachamber.com. ANNUAL MEETING, STATE OF THE CITY We’re planning our annual meeting with the State of the City address and Business Advocate Hall of Fame induction luncheon at 11:30 a.m. Jan. 18 at the Suncoast Technical College, 4445 Career Lane Way in North Port. Lunch will be catered by Longhorn Steakhouse-Port Charlotte. We will induct the recipient of the 2024 Business Advocate Hall of Fame. This award is designed to recognize and honor an individual who has dedicated their time and efforts in support of the business community and economic development. The recipient’s name will be included on a plaque that will be displayed at our office and will receive a recognition award at the luncheon. We are proud to announce that the recipient of the 2024 Business Advocate Hall of Fame Award will go to Tony Gustitus of the Rhonda Gustitus Team-Keller Williams Peace River Partners. The luncheon will also include a State of the City address by North Port city manager Jerome Fletcher, and we will present our Annual Report to the chamber membership. Tickets are $35 for chamber members and guests. Full-table and half-table sponsorships are. Reservation deadline is Jan. 15. Register at www.northportareachamber.com. NORTH PORT YOUNG PROFESSIONALS The North Port Young Professionals will hold their first New Year’s monthly social at 5:30 p.m. Thursday at Beef ‘O’ Brady’s, 1037 Sumter Blvd. These monthly socials are open to everyone from 20-45 years old and are free, unless you wish to order food and drinks. Come out and enjoy some great networking with your peers and bring your business cards and door prizes to gain additional exposure for yourself and your business/organization. Register at www.northportyp.com. NEW MEMBERS We would like to welcome Beauty and Wellness Med Spa and NAMI Sarasota and Manatee Counties as new members of the North Port Area Chamber of commerce.

organizations.name: north port area chamber of commerce

author: Maddy Lauria
title: Terrarium startup OBEnaturelle tops 2023 Hen Hatch - Delaware Business Times
text: Terrarium startup OBEnaturelle tops 2023 Hen Hatch Share NEWARK – Lauren Roberts caught the entrepreneurial bug at a young age. When the Newark resident was only in third grade, she had already launched her own small business selling fake nails made from paper. Over the years, she would evolve to selling candies and crafts she’d created through the unofficial “Lauren’s Galore Store.” Now, the 20-year-old University of Delaware sophomore has a full-fledged small business focused on plants — an endeavor that already netted her $20,000 in revenue in its first six months and earned the attention of a panel of judges at this year’s Hen Hatch startup competition. “What I have right now is an established system,” she said, noting that the company she started right before high school paused for a while as she transitioned to college. Now, with the support and earnings from the latest contest and other offerings through UD, Roberts hopes to focus more on marketing and scaling her company to get it back to that initial success. The pitch for [her company](https://obenaturelle.com/), OBEnaturelle, which not only offers direct sales of plants, terrarium kits and other merchandise but also corporate or private workshops and parties, caught the attention of the contest’s four judges: Dave Liss, of W.L. Gore & Associates, Mac Macleod, of Carvertise; Wendy Scott, of Blue Blaze Associates; and Glenn Glady, of Robin Hood Ventures. Roberts topped all finalists in this year’s Hen Hatch contest, taking with her $8,300 in funding, $1,000 in Shoprite gift cards and over 30 hours of legal, marketing and workforce services. Hen Hatch is UD Horn Entrepreneurship’s “premier pitch competition,” explained faculty coordinator Daniel Lee, an assistant professor in the Alfred Lerner College of Business & Economics. The multi-round contest starts in the summer with students submitting a multi-page business plan, then moves on to the semifinals and mentoring before whittling down to the four final entrepreneurs who [presented this fall](https://horn.udel.edu/an-epicenter-for-innovation-2023-hen-hatchs-final-round). “It’s important for the students because it gets them boots-on-the-ground experience pitching to a panel of investors,” Lee said. “It’s important to them also because they get help and feedback on these student-run ventures.” It also gives the surrounding business community a closer look at the entrepreneurial spirit and talent coming from the university, while also staying connected to the local business community, he said. Roberts, who is studying entrepreneurship and on track to graduate in 2026, joined marketing student Ian Drogowitz, entrepreneurship and fashion merchandising major Samantha McGhee and entrepreneurship and management student Nicholai Williamson as this year’s Hen Hatch finalists. Lee said this year’s finalists focused a lot on what he would call “disruptive business models” rather than deep-tech or intellectual property. Businesses like ONEnaturelle are those that have already been deployed in the market, and not something that needs years of development in a laboratory. “When you’re in the mid-Atlantic, it’s sort of easy to overlook Delaware. It’s a small state. In northern Delaware, you can look to Philly for a lot of these innovations,” Lee said. “But we have a bunch of [bright, young minds](https://delawarebusinesstimes.com/news/hospitality-app-uds-hen-hatch/) working on really cool things at UD.”

author: Pablo Codd
title: Pedagogía en Educación Parvularia de la UCN obtuvo la máxima acreditación para carreras sin egresados y egresadas
text:
Hito marca un precedente en la educación parvularia del Norte del país.
La Facultad de Educación de la Universidad Católica del Norte (UCN), recibió el dictamen de la Comisión Nacional de Acreditación (CNA), que otorgó por unanimidad la acreditación de la carrera de Pedagogía en Educación Parvularia con Mención en Desarrollo Emocional y Cognitivo por un período de tres años, el máximo para carreras sin egresados y egresadas.
Tras años de trabajo, el equipo de autoevaluación lideró un proceso de gran impacto en la formación de educadores y educadoras de párvulo que culminó con la acreditación que entra en vigencia a partir del 4 de diciembre del 2024. La carrera es la segunda en la UCN acreditada con los nuevos estándares de aseguramiento de la calidad de la CNA para las pedagogías.
La Dra. Patricia Castillo Ladino, decana de la Facultad de Educación de la UCN, destacó este logro. “Constituye un importante acicate para seguir contribuyendo a la formación inicial docente en el Norte de Chile, lo que nos posiciona como una universidad de excelencia. Sin duda, este proceso de autoevaluación y su resultado, viene a robustecer el aporte al desarrollo profesional de docentes en el norte y nos desafía a seguir avanzando como institución en la formación de masa crítica de excelencia para así garantizar el derecho a la educación de los niños y niñas en el país. Este resultado es el fruto del trabajo de profesionales muy comprometidos con la revalorización social de la labor docente” enfatizó.
La carrera de Pedagogía en Educación Parvularia con Mención en Desarrollo Emocional y Cognitivo abrió su admisión en 2021 y es una de las primeras carreras en el Norte del país en ofrecer un plan de estudios que aborda el bienestar emocional de las infancias en contextos educativos. Con esta carrera profesional, la Facultad de Educación UCN establece una línea de formación en educación de párvulos que atiende las necesidades del territorio.
La académica Paola Ponce, jefa de Carrera de Pedagogía en Educación Parvularia con Mención en Desarrollo Emocional y Cognitivo, señala que conseguir la máxima acreditación para una carrera sin egresados fue un inmenso logro. “Como carrera nueva en su tercer año de implementación nos orientamos a cumplir altos estándares de calidad, niveles de competencias y logros de aprendizajes en los futuros egresados y egresadas de la educación parvularia. Queremos seguir creciendo en esta nueva etapa, seguir perfeccionando nuestros procesos y empezar a trabajar en la mira de una nueva acreditación que ojalá venga por siete años”, comentó.
Asimismo, Pía Cavallero, educadora de párvulo, académica y encargada de Acreditación de la carrera de Pedagogía en Educación Parvularia, puso de relieve este logro. “Fue un proceso arduo y de gran dedicación, durante el cual se logró la convocatoria y participación de académicos, profesionales de apoyo, estudiantes y comunidad en general. Esta noticia es una inyección de éxito para la carrera”.
Según datos entregados por la Subsecretaría de Educación Parvularia y Elige Educar, se proyecta un déficit importante de educadores y educadoras de párvulos para el año 2034. Por lo que la apertura de la carrera y su acreditación contribuyen significativamente en disminuir esta carencia de profesionales en la Macrozona Norte.
Con la apertura de las nuevas carreras de pedagogía y la acreditación de ambas, la UCN reafirma su compromiso con la formación de profesores y profesoras en el Norte de Chile.

author: Ground News
title: Ground News - Assam CM apologises for Bhagavad Gita-based social media post on castes
text:
Summary by Ground News Assam Chief Minister Himanta Biswa Sarma has apologised for a Bhagavad Gita-based social media post on the Varna or caste system in Hinduism. He attributed the deleted post to an incorrect translation of verse 44 from chapter 18 of the Gita by a team member. Share menu More

author: Radio-Canada
title: Vents intenses prévus dans le sud des T.N.-O : les autorités aux aguets | Radio-Canada
text: Vents intenses prévus dans le sud des T.N.-O : les autorités aux aguets Une photo de 2021 d'un feu de forêt dans la région du Dehcho. Un feu de forêt est actuellement combattu près de Fort Liard. Photo : Fournie par le ministère de l'Environnement et des Ressources naturelles Les autorités de gestion des feux de forêt des Territoires du Nord-Ouest avisent les résidents des régions du Slave Sud et du Dehcho d’un risque accru d’activité, vendredi, en raison de l’arrivée d’un épisode de vents violents. D'après leur porte-parole, Mike Westwick, des rafales pourraient atteindre de 50 à 70 km/h, avec des températures à la hausse qui pourraient dépasser les 20 degrés Celsius, asséchant ainsi l’humidité atmosphérique. S’il y a un feu sur le terrain, il est probable qu’il puisse grossir rapidement et qu’il devienne difficile de le contrôler. À lire aussi : Nouveau feu dans le Dehcho Au total, sept feux de forêt ont été détectés jusqu’ici cette année, parmi lesquels trois demeurent actifs. Plus récemment, un incendie à 23 km au sud-ouest de Fort Liard, dans la région du Dehcho, a précipité les équipes de lutte contre les incendies sur place. Des avions-citernes ont été dépêchés sur les lieux pour appuyer les efforts des pompiers au sol. L’incendie s'étend désormais sur six hectares. Aucune communauté ni structure n’est menacée, précisent les autorités, quoique le risque d'incendie demeure extrême au cours des prochains jours pour le secteur. Fort Smith à risque Dans la région de Fort Smith, particulièrement touchée par les feux de forêt l’an dernier, l’événement météorologique pourrait s’accompagner de foudre, un déclencheur important d'incendies dans la forêt boréale. L'été dernier, Fort Smith avait été la cible de nombreux feux de forêt entraînant l'évacuation de la communauté. Photo : Radio-Canada / Julie Beaver Mike Westwick assure que les pompiers sont à l'œuvre pour limiter la propagation des feux déjà en activité afin de prévenir, au mieux, une propagation plus importante vendredi. Il rappelle aux résidents qui ont l’intention de se rendre dans l’arrière-pays de se faire le plus prudent possible pour éviter de déclencher de nouveaux feux. Les autorités anticipent toutefois que les niveaux d’humidité iront en augmentant près de Fort Smith et de Hay River à mesure que les pointes de vent diminueront samedi.

author: Paul Fogarty
title: Former Apple employee shares how to reactivate 'essential' iPhone feature removed on new models
text:
When Apple released the iPhone X and tweaked the layout of the screen, the ability to see your current battery percentage automatically was removed, something that persists on the latest models. You can still see it if you open the control center but the default view will simply just show your battery level as a bar.
However, former
Apple employee and TikTok content creator, Tyler Morgan – known by the username @hitomidocameraroll – has revealed that you can reactivate this time-saving feature in a new video alongside a host of other helpful hints and tips.
Reactivate your iPhone battery percentage number
If you want to be able to see your
iPhone battery percentage at the top of your screen at all times, Tyler instructs viewers to: “Go to your Settings, go to your Battery settings and ensure ‘Battery Percentage’ is enabled.”
Despite it being a relatively simple process, it’s one that many have clearly been missing as the caption of Tyler’s video reveals it’s been a heavily requested tip.
“For all the people DMing me about battery percentage, there you go,” Tyler says.
- OLD VS NEW:
Swapping your smartphone for a ‘dumbphone’ could be the answer to social media addiction
Volume adjusting automatically
If you find that your iPhone volume level has a mind of its own, it’s because you have Attention-Aware features turned on.
To disable these, Tyler says: “Go to your Settings, go down to Accessibility, Face ID and Attention and turn off ‘Attention-Aware Features.”
MORE FOCUS STORIES
Clicking typing sound
For some strange reason, iPhones will automatically play clicking sounds when you type, despite the fact that it can be incredibly annoying for not only yourself and those around you.
If you do find this setting to be an annoyance, “go to Sounds and Haptics, Keyboard Feedback and you can choose if you want the sound or not,” explains Tyler.
“You can just have the haptic on which I feel like most people will appreciate,” he adds, before inserting a
clip of actor Cillian Murphy sharing his own frustrations of people who leave the clicking sounds on.
Turn off ‘Always On’ display
Depending on your iPhone model, you can choose to have your display in Always On mode.
But if this isn’t for you, Tyler says head to “Display and Brightness, [scroll] all the way down, you’re going to see Always On Display, turn it off.”
Decide how long before your screen auto-locks
This setting is really down to personal preference but if you find that your phone screen takes too much or not enough time to auto-lock, you can change this timeframe in the settings.
Also found within Display and Brightness, this can be changed under the Auto-Lock setting. Tyler says, “Personally I feel like two minutes is ok.”
Improve video quality
If you’re a budding filmmaker or simply want to improve the quality of the videos you post to social media, you can tweak the quality settings of your videos.
However, it should be noted that doing so will increase the size of their files, so if your phone’s a little tight on space this tip may not be for you.
Tyler says: “In your Settings, go to your Camera, Record Video, [choose] 4K at 60 fps or whatever you prefer.”
Choose when to carry out software updates
And finally, if you’re not keen on Apple automatically adding new features to your iPhone that you know you’ll never use, you can decide to prevent software updates from downloading by themselves.
“You should be the one to choose if you want to download the newest update or not,” says Tyler. “For this, go to General, Software Update, [and] turn iOS updates off.”
In this setting, Apple also lets you decide if you want to update ‘Security Responses and System Files,’ and as this could help to protect your device from hackers or viruses, it’s wise to leave this on.

author: Shafat Malik
title: Two young prodigies from J&K awarded PM Rashtriya Bal Puraskar 2024
text:
Srinagar, Dec 26: Two young talents from Jammu and Kashmir on Thursday received Pradhan Mantri Rashtriya Bal Puraskar (PMRBP) 2024 from President Droupadi Murmu for their outstanding contributions in their respective fields.
Ayaan Sajad, a 12-year-old Sufi singer from South Kashmir’s Anantnag district was honoured upon by President Droupadi Murmu honoured with the Pradhan Mantri Rashtriya Bal Puraskar in the Art and Culture category at Rashtrapati Bhavan. Ayaan, a 12-year-old singer from Kashmir, gained widespread recognition for his rendition of the Kashmiri song “BeDard Dadi Chane,” which blends Sufi themes with pop-rap elements.
Ayan has already made a name for himself through his soulful renditions of traditional Sufi music. His dedication to the art form and his ability to connect with his audience through his powerful voice have earned him widespread recognition.
The award, which is one of the highest honors for children in India, recognizes extraordinary contributions in various fields, including innovation, social service, scholastic achievements, sports, bravery, and art.
Celebrating Ayaan’s achievement, Lieutenant Governor Manoj Sinha in a post on “X” said, “Congratulations to Master Ayaan Sajad on receiving Pradhan Mantri Rashtriya Bal Puraskar from Hon’ble President Smt. Droupadi Murmu Ji. He is a singer par excellence. I wish Ayaan all the best for future endeavours. May you inspire many more youngsters across J&K UT.”
Similarly, Risheek Kumar, a 17-year-old cyber security prodigy from Samba district of Jammu, was also honored with the Pradhan Mantri Rashtriya Bal Puraskar for his work in cyber security.
Risheek has made a name for himself as the founder of J&K’s first cybersecurity company “Hackers Patshala”.
His innovative spirit and exceptional skills in the digital field have earned him significant accolades, including recognition at the Future Crime Summit, where he was named the Future Crime Researcher of the Year.
The Future Crime Summit, one of the largest cyber security conferences in India, recognized Risheek’s contributions to protecting people from digital threats.
At the award ceremony, Risheek was honored for his visionary work in cyber security, which has the potential to shape the future of digital security in India and beyond.
Lieutenant Governor Manoj Sinha also congratulated Risheek for his work. In a Post on “X”, LG Sinha said, “Master Risheek Kumar from Samba brings laurels by receiving Pradhan Mantri Rashtriya Bal Puraskar from Hon’ble President Smt. Droupadi Murmu Ji for his pioneering work in cyber security. Many congratulations Risheek. Your brilliance and innovative spirit will inspire young minds.”
Chief Minister Omar Abdullah and National Conference President Farooq Abdullah extended their heartfelt congratulations to both the young achievers. In a joint statement, they praised Ayaan and Risheek for their extraordinary contributions, noting that their achievements are a source of immense pride for the people of Jammu and Kashmir.
They expressed hope that their dedication and excellence would continue to inspire young minds across the region and beyond.
In their message, both leaders emphasized the importance of nurturing talent in all fields, encouraging the youth of J&K to pursue their passions and strive for excellence.
Two young prodigies from J&K awarded PM Rashtriya Bal Puraskar 2024
Ayaan Sajad's sufi music, Risheek Kumar's cybersecurity excellence earn national recognition

author: Devdiscourse News Desk
title: Boeing Workers Strike for First Time Since 2008, Halting 737 MAX Production | Law-Order
text: Boeing Workers Strike for First Time Since 2008, Halting 737 MAX Production Boeing factory workers on the U.S. West Coast will strike after 96% voted in favor. The strike begins Friday, halting 737 MAX production. Despite a proposed contract offering wage hikes and bonuses, workers rejected it, demanding higher pay. CEO Kelly Ortberg and union leaders urged acceptance, but the strike proceeds. [Devdiscourse News Desk](/devdiscourse-stories)| Updated: 13-09-2024 10:15 IST | Created: 13-09-2024 10:15 IST Boeing's factory workers on the U.S. West Coast are set to strike after 96% voted in favor, which will halt the production of the 737 MAX. This significant move comes as Boeing battles production delays and increasing debt. The strike, starting just after midnight Pacific time on Friday, follows the recent appointment of CEO Kelly Ortberg, who was tasked with regaining trust in the planemaker following several setbacks. Approximately 30,000 workers involved in producing Boeing's jets in Seattle and Portland were casting ballots on their first full contract in 16 years. Despite a proposed contract including a 25% general wage increase, a $3,000 signing bonus, and a commitment to build Boeing's next commercial jet in Seattle, workers overwhelmingly rejected it, seeking a 40% pay rise and criticizing the loss of an annual bonus. Union rules required at least two-thirds of workers to approve strike action, and they did so overwhelmingly, despite leadership recommending acceptance. (With inputs from agencies.) ALSO READ [Sri Lanka's Fragile Debt Path: A Warning from the Foreign Minister](/article/headlines/3067448-sri-lankas-fragile-debt-path-a-warning-from-the-foreign-minister) [Assam's Debt Soars Over 107% in Four Years: CAG Report](/article/headlines/3068993-assams-debt-soars-over-107-in-four-years-cag-report) [New Boeing CEO Kelly Ortberg Addresses Regulatory Scrutiny with FAA](/article/business/3069430-new-boeing-ceo-kelly-ortberg-addresses-regulatory-scrutiny-with-faa) [Boeing CEO Kelly Ortberg Confronts FAA Regulatory Scrutiny Amid Safety Concerns](/article/business/3069447-boeing-ceo-kelly-ortberg-confronts-faa-regulatory-scrutiny-amid-safety-concerns) [Tragic End of Debt-Ridden Family in Chhattisgarh](/article/entertainment/3070585-tragic-end-of-debt-ridden-family-in-chhattisgarh)
